Hello, Saurabh -- I also am interested in doing focused crawling with
Heretrix.  I did some work in focused crawling a year or so ago using
Mercator (one of the progenitors of Heretrix).  I think hooking in an
analyzer is a good idea; with my focused crawling I did all the
analysis of page contents on the fly as pages were being downloaded,
rather than from files.  Doing on-the-fly analysis is actually a good
idea; most processors have way too much CPU speed so you can do all
the matching you want, while your threads are politely downloading
more pages.  I didn't have any fancy machine learning analyzers,
though (but I wanted to move on to that); just strictly TF-IDF.

iVia is (in my opinion) the foremost group right now doing automated
classification based on web-crawling for technical subjects.  In fact,
I was so impressed with their work that I gave up on my own, urging my
organization to contract with iVia instead of having me repeat the work.

If you are interested in hooking up for a focused crawling project
using Heretrix, I am too!  Why don't you contact me offline (if you
are interested) and see what we can cook up?

D. Bergmark (retired from Cornell CS Department)

P.S. Maybe we could implement the "Focused Crawl Option" you wrote about.

P.P.S.  Probably no single option would work across the genres of
technical, business, entertainment, ... I got really good focused
crawling results for topics in physics and mathematics, but really
rotten results for topics in French International Law.
